dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news from Tokyo, B. It looks like overseas spectators *are* gonna be allowed to attend the Summer Olympics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big news from Tokyo, B. It looks like overseas spectators are gonna be allowed to attend the Summer Olympics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overseas spectators will be prohibited from attending the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, the games' organizing committee announced Saturday...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that was the big announcement Saturday from the organizing committee. I mean, they're really hoping this helps calm down some of the, uh, concerns from Japanese citizens about potential COVID outbreaks, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that was the big announcement Saturday from the organizing committee. I mean, they're really hoping this helps calm down some of the, uh, concerns from Japanese citizens about potential C O V I D outbreaks, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overseas spectators will be prohibited from attending the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, the games' organizing committee announced Saturday, a move they hope will mitigate the concerns of Japanese citizens over the risk that the games will seed Covid-19 outbreaks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And, like, this decision was made purely with the International Olympic Committee's endorsement, too. Not just, you know, Tokyo's call.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And, like, this decision was made purely with the International Olympic Committee's endorsement, too. Not just, you know, Tokyo's call.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee made the decision jointly with national and local governments in Japan and the International Olympic and Paralympic Committees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And get this, A, they'd sold, what, about a million tickets overseas? Though the AP says it's closer to 600,000. Either way, a lot of people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And get this, A, they'd sold, what, about a million tickets overseas? Though the A P says it's closer to six hundred thousand. Either way, a lot of people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the organizers, approximately 600,000 tickets were sold overseas, although the Associated Press reported that number is closer to 1 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, what about refunds? Because I can imagine a lot of people were like, "Are we even going?"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, what about refunds? Because I can imagine a lot of people were like, Are we even going?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, here's the thing. The committee said no refunds on the tickets themselves. *But*, [interrupts] Muto, the CEO, he said they'd cover cancellation fees for flights and hotels. So, a bit of a mixed bag there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, here's the thing. The committee said no refunds on the tickets themselves. But, Muto, the C E O, he said they'd cover cancellation fees for flights and hotels. So, a bit of a mixed bag there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee asserted that refunds for tickets would be issued, but Tokyo 2020 Chief Executive Officer Toshiro Muto said cancellation fees related to airline travel and accommodations previously booked would not be covered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And they still haven't decided on capacity limits for domestic spectators, either. That's, like, still up in the air.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And they still haven't decided on capacity limits for domestic spectators, either. That's, like, still up in the air.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Muto said a determination on capacity limits at venues for domestic spectators would be made before the end of next month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. I mean, Japan's actually handled the pandemic pretty well, compared to most places, right? Fewer than 460,000 cases, 9,000 deaths. But still, there's a lot of local apprehension.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. I mean, Japan's actually handled the pandemic pretty well, compared to most places, right? Fewer than four hundred sixty thousand cases, nine thousand deaths. But still, there's a lot of local apprehension.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although Japan has managed the pandemic better than most countries, with fewer than 460,000 confirmed cases and 9,000 deaths nationwide...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. I read that about 20% of Japanese actually think the games should be postponed again or just canceled outright.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. I read that about twenty percent of Japanese actually think the games should be postponed again or just canceled outright.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 80% of Japanese believe the games, which are scheduled to begin in July, should be postponed again or canceled altogether, according to a survey by national broadcaster NHK.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's according to NHK. And you've got, what, 15,400 athletes entering, plus coaches, officials... it's a huge undertaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's according to N H K. And you've got, what, fifteen thousand, four hundred athletes entering, plus coaches, officials... it's a huge undertaking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 15,400 athletes will enter Japan to compete, in addition to coaches, officials, sponsors and members of the media.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. And the torch relay actually starts this Wednesday, too, in Okinawa. Five months long, 100,000 runners. That's quite the production.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. And the torch relay actually starts this Wednesday, too, in Okinawa. Five months long, one hundred thousand runners. That's quite the production.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The torch relay for the games will begin Thursday in Fukushima Prefecture and will last four months, with roughly 10,000 runners traversing the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is. And it's interesting, because earlier this week, PM Suga actually announced an extension of Tokyo's state of emergency. Though, uh, the advisory panel kinda rejected that plan later. So, even that's a bit up in the air.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is. And it's interesting, because earlier this week, P M Suga actually announced an extension of Tokyo's state of emergency. Though, uh, the advisory panel kinda rejected that plan later. So, even that's a bit up in the air.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this week, Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced the government planned to lift the state of emergency in Tokyo on Sunday. ... On Thursday, the Japanese government's advisory panel on coronavirus countermeasures approved the plan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Always something, right? It's just... I mean, it's such a complex situation trying to pull this off during a global pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Always something, right? It's just... I mean, it's such a complex situation trying to pull this off during a global pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. A lot of moving parts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. A lot of moving parts.
